text: [Music]
hello this is chef john from food wishes
comm with thai dipped you try to that's
right we really should have called this
satay soaked beef tri-tip but
unfortunately that didn't run but anyway
i've always wanted to try this little
twist on one of my favorite all-time
asian marinades pause since we're
heading right into the middle of
grilling season it's never a bad idea to
remind people how great and
user-friendly the tri-tip roast is and
we'll be getting to the beef briefly but
first we have to put together our
marinade which will do quite simply by
adding the following ingredients to a
mixing bowl and we'll start with a whole
bunch of minced garlic followed by some
bruised and chopped up lemongrass which
by the way i'm going to give you a few
tips about on the blog post we're also
going to add a ton of finely grated
ginger root as well as if you don't mind
shedding a few tears some grated onion
and that's going to do it for our
aromatic vegetable base which means we
can continue on with a whole bunch of
fish sauce which a lot of people are
afraid of because they don't understand
what it is okay once you learn this is
nothing more than the liquid that comes
off decomposing fish you realize there's
nothing to fear and then we're also
going to go ahead and add a little bit
of soy sauce
as well as some seasoned rice vinegar
which is rice vinegar they make with a
little bit of salt and sugar in it and
then of course we're going to want to
spice this up which i'm going to do with
some ground coriander some ground cumin
as well as some gorgeously colored
tumeric and that is going to be it for
the spices just kidding of course we're
going to put a little cayenne and then
to finish this up we'll go ahead and
dump in some brown sugar which we're
going to want in here to balance out all
these intense flavors and then last but
not least a little bit of vegetable oil
for reasons I'd rather not discuss just
put it in and then we'll go ahead and
take a whisk and give this a mix and
that's it our Thai inspired beef satay
ish marinade is done and normally that
would now be ready to toss in hundreds
of little pieces of beef that we would
marinate and then skewer before grilling
but I've always wanted to try this as a
marinade for a large hunk of meat to put
on the grill in particular a beef
tri-tip roast and there it is apparently
named for his triangular shape which I
believe is cut from the bottom sirloin
and not only is this a relatively
affordable piece of meat but it's also
very user friendly and doesn't require
much trimming as well as there's really
no
owns our connective tissue so we pretty
much kateed all of it and what we'll do
is transfer that into our marinade so we
can give it the old poke and soak so
let's toss that in and then take a fork
and poke it all over like I don't know
16 to 75 times and now don't count we'll
just do that until we think it's good we
are after all the Tribe Called Quest of
how many posts is best I was actually
trying to work in a q-tip reference but
I couldn't figure out how to do it but
anyway once our beef has been coated
thoroughly and poked severely what we'll
do is cover that and let it marinate in
the fridge for anywhere between 2 and 12
hours and whenever I marinade in a bowl
like this it's not a bad idea to pull it
out once in a while and give it a toss
as well as some additional poking so I
did that a few times in case you're
keeping score at home I let my marinade
for exactly four hours at which point
we're going to pull it out of the
marinade and I like to set it down on
some paper towels it during just a
little bit it probably doesn't matter at
all but I do like to brush off few of
the chunks and then assuming that our
coals are ready we can head outside and
get to roasting and yes I did say
roasting not grilling I'm actually going
to cook mine over interact fairly low
heats all right my cooking temperature
ranged between 300 and 325 for most of
the cooking and I'm going to give you
some different options on the blog four
ways to cook this but for a little
change of pace I decide to go low and
slow another than brushing on some of
the marinade and maybe turning it once
in a while I didn't really do anything
except wait for it to get to an internal
temp of 130 to 135 which remains the
ideal temperature to cook this too all
right we don't want to cook this too
rare because like things like flank
steak and skirt steak it can be kind of
chewy if we under cook it so I did check
with a thermometer and pulled mine off
at about 132 and head it inside to let
it rest
oh and quick tip if you have some extra
marinade which you probably will what we
can do is bring that to a boil to
sterilize it and then that's safe to
brush on our meat or serve on the side
or whatever so I did brush out a little
more not that it really needs it but I
did want to show you you have to boil it
if you're going to use it but anyway as
usual we're going to let that meat rest
at least 10 to 15 minutes truth be told
I got a phone call so actually that mine
rest about a half hour but it was still
beautiful as you're about to see as I
cut in here and my first cut did go
right into the center because I wanted
to see how moist
amazingly beautiful this was but then I
remembered I always like to take a few
slices off the edge and if the driest
most cooked parts are still moist and
delicious then I know the rest of its
going to be awesome and as I was cutting
I could not believe how tender this felt
I also couldn't believe I wasn't cutting
across a grain I blame the amazing smell
in appearance as well as my debilitating
hunger but you know what even though it
wasn't from the middle and I sort of cut
it with the grain it was still
absolutely incredible tender flavorful
moist and many many other adjectives it
was basically a perfect piece of sliced
roast beef that tastes like beef satay
so I went ahead and sliced up some more
the right way against the grain which by
the way is pretty easy to see on a
tri-tip and while this meat was quite
delicious on its own when I added my
favorite satay condiments which would be
some peanut sauce and a spicy cucumber
salad it became even more fantastic so I
decided to plate them up and eat some
more and by the way you wouldn't know by
watching this video but some people shy
away from tri-tip because it has a
reputation for being kind of tough and
chewy but I'm telling you using this
technique it was not at all and I'm
really not sure how much of that is the
marinade ingredients and how much of it
was that low slow cooking but I really
was absolutely thrilled with how this
came out but anyway that's it what I'm
calling tidy up to beef tri-tip if
you're a fan of beef satay but not
necessarily a fan of securing hundreds
of little pieces of beef then I really
do hope you give this delicious
alternative a try soon so head over to
food wishes dot-com for all the
ingredient amounts and Markel as usual
and as always enjoy
you
